Hey folks! :sunny: thank you for joining us for Ask Apple. We’re excited to kick off a week of Q&A activities. We’ll start this morning with a *Q&A for SF Symbols 4*, beginning *at 9:00am PT.* We hope you can tune-in live! The workflow is open now if you’d like to begin submitting questions related to SF Symbols. Select the:heavy_plus_sign:icon from the lower left, and find the _Ask A Question_ workflow. Type in your question and the team will answer as many questions as they can during the 60 minute event this morning.

We have a few other Q&A’s happening later this week. Please hold off on submitting questions for those activities until the previous activity has concluded. This helps us answer questions more efficiently! Thank you for understanding.

If you have some time before we kick this off, make sure you’re caught up on videos from WWDC22, _What’s new in SF Symbols 4_ and _Adopt Variable Color in SF Symbols._

messages.text:
<@U045NGKNMPH> asked
> I would like to include a symbol of a book with a heart overlayed on top of it, to signify a diary is marked as favourite.
> 
> I'm currently achieving this using `Image(systemName: "text.book.closed")` with an overlay and offset modifier of a heart.  What are the pros and cons of using this approach instead of drawing my own custom symbol?
> 
> Thanks so much to the team for all the work this year and previously – can't imagine how bland my apps would look without SF Symbols! :smile:

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Nicholas!

The main pro I can think of would be being able to change things at runtime, like if you wanted to swap out a different symbol for the heart or move it around. If you're more comfortable in code than in a vector graphics tool, this approach would also skip the custom symbol workflow.

On the flip side, the cons are that you'll be opting-out of a lot of the automatic behavior that SF Symbols provides. A custom symbol will respond more automatically to different weights (the heart will likely need to move to account for thicker lines), but with the code approach, you'd need to detect the weight and move the heart on your own. You also will need to manage the colors of the book symbol and heart symbol separately, whereas a custom symbol can use the built-in rendering modes to do this.

elements.text:

On the flip side, the cons are that you'll be opting-out of a lot of the automatic behavior that SF Symbols provides. A custom symbol will respond more automatically to different weights (the heart will likely need to move to account for thicker lines), but with the code approach, you'd need to detect the weight and move the heart on your own. You also will need to manage the colors of the book symbol and heart symbol separately, whereas a custom symbol can use the built-in rendering modes to do this.

messages.text:
This might be a good time to remind everyone about variable templates! Instead of having to draw all 27 different combinations of scale and weight, variable templates allow you to just draw 3, and let the system take care of the rest for you!

The SF Symbols app will even take care of "flattening out" the other combinations if you need to back-deploy to systems that only support the 2.0 symbol templates.

Hello :wave: and welcome to Day Two of Ask Apple, <#C043CM5G9LH|> edition! All week long, we’re offering Q&A’s and one-on-one consultations to share insight, support, and design guidance for your apps — directly from Apple experts.

This morning, the topic is *Design great widgets for the Lock Screen*. As of iOS 16, you can use WidgetKit to deliver glanceable information to the Lock Screen. Join us for a conversation about the right information to display, and the design language of the Lock Screen. We’ll get started at *9:00am PT*.

> We are building functionality into our app to allow passengers to reserve a spot in the TSA line at an airport.  When they show up to check in we will scan their QR code.  It would be nice if the QR code is available from the Lock Screen.  If we are offering them a PassKit pass for their wallet, is that enough or should we add a Lock Screen widget.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"We are building functionality into our app to allow passengers to reserve a spot in the TSA line at an airport.  When they show up to check in we will scan their QR code.  It would be nice if the QR code is available from the Lock Screen.  If we are offering them a PassKit pass for their wallet, is that enough or should we add a Lock Screen widget."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: A Lock Screen widget could show timely glanceable information, if your app is able to know that it’s the time for TSA check-in, and provide a method to tap-in to launch the app and view the QR Code. However, this would mean that the user would need to already have your app’s widget on the Lock Screen ahead of time, but we would encourage users to set up separate lock screens for different activities (such as work or travel).

elements.text: A Lock Screen widget could show timely glanceable information, if your app is able to know that it’s the time for TSA check-in, and provide a method to tap-in to launch the app and view the QR Code. However, this would mean that the user would need to already have your app’s widget on the Lock Screen ahead of time, but we would encourage users to set up separate lock screens for different activities (such as work or travel).

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi <@U046X6E720Y>, a couple of more thoughts here: I think it’s a good idea to offer both. I think it’s likely that people will set up a lock screen that provides access to things that they’ll use on a day of travel — ride share apps, airline apps, etc — and PassKit will allow you to ensure that the pass is presented in a familiar way

messages.text:
<@U04635ASQAW> asked
> Some circular widgets have a visible background layer. Others don’t. And you almost never see a rectangular widget with a background.
> 
> When is it (in)appropriate to use a background?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Some circular widgets have a visible background layer. Others don\u2019t. And you almost never see a rectangular widget with a background.\n\nWhen is it (in)appropriate to use a background?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
We use the blurred Accessory Background material on the circular widgets that don’t already have a circular element, to help define their shape and bring visual balance when they’re next to other widgets. For example, a temperature gauge already defines the shape of the widget and doesn’t need an additional background, but a completely text-based World Clock in a circular widget has better balance with other widgets when it has the visible background.

We discourage the use of backgrounds on rectangular widgets because we don’t want to hide a large portion of the user’s photograph or wallpaper.

We discourage the use of backgrounds on rectangular widgets because we don’t want to hide a large portion of the user’s photograph or wallpaper.

<@U046JMFLKV3> asked
> Some application have a widget just as a "shortcut" to open the application from the lockscreen.
> From a design perspective, do you think this approach is what was intended for the lockscreen? 
> Especially when the key information from the app cannot fit in the small size?
> And if so, do you think the app should try to open regulary, or try to resolve the most probable info the user intended ? (like the closest spot in his addresses list)

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Some application have a widget just as a "shortcut" to open the application from the lockscreen.
From a design perspective, do you think this approach is what was intended for the lockscreen? 
Especially when the key information from the app cannot fit in the small size?
And if so, do you think the app should try to open regulary, or try to resolve the most probable info the user intended ? (like the closest spot in his addresses list)"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We discourage using Lock Screen widgets only as shortcuts into an app, the design intention is for them to be used to display glanceable information. Tapping on a widget should be a secondary action and not a requirement — for example a user can see at a glance that the current temperature is 72°, and tap to launch into the app for a more detailed forecast. The tap should be optional, and only if the user wants to dive deeper.

The tap should be optional, and only if the user wants to dive deeper.

<@U046S5LM1H6> asked
> We have a motivation quote app. We try to show the quote on the lock screen but certain quote is too long. Would you recommend truncate the quote to motivate user click into the app or just make the text smaller?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"We have a motivation quote app. We try to show the quote on the lock screen but certain quote is too long. Would you recommend truncate the quote to motivate user click into the app or just make the text smaller?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Or further to that, is there an option to scroll the text? (automatically)

elements.text: Or further to that, is there an option to scroll the text? (automatically)

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You do have some flexibility in reducing the size of the text, but keep in mind that the widgets might be placed over complex photographs and wallpaper backgrounds. We would recommend keeping the text short and glanceable rather than reducing the size to make things fit. Using shorter quotes on the Lock Screen or editing them to fit might be better, instead of relying on automatic truncation.

One example is the Apple News widget which did reduce the text size and adopted a condensed style of type to reflect the visual style of their headlines, which also helped them squeeze in more text. However, I’d recommend that you don’t deviate too far from your app’s visual style — in this case News was able to successfully use Condensed because it mimics the style of the headlines in the app.

messages.text: Question for <@U044D6PTPN1>: Are there any specific design recommendations that you think would help make a great Lock Screen widget?

elements.text: Question for
: Are there any specific design recommendations that you think would help make a great Lock Screen widget?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
There’s very little space to work with, and of course glanceability of information should take the center stage. Make sure that your design should feels visual consistent with other widgets, but it’s great to find ways to incorporate your own app’s visual language in the widget. For example,

Apple News uses a typographic style that matches headlines in the app, and Reminders brings forward the visual cue of the empty circles to show unchecked tasks.

Use Symbols whenever possible — at a glance the Moon widget in Weather feels visually different from other three-line rectangular text widgets because of its use of SF Symbols

messages.text:
<@U04656V5MGU> asked
> Do you have design guidance for displaying multiple lines of text? For example, I'm considering putting the app name on line 1, the first item from the list on line 2, then +8 more on line 3. Or the first two items from the list and then the last line saying +7 more without the app name.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you have design guidance for displaying multiple lines of text? For example, I'm considering putting the app name on line 1, the first item from the list on line 2, then +8 more on line 3. Or the first two items from the list and then the last line saying +7 more without the app name."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
We don’t recommend displaying your app’s name, it’s better to make use of Symbols or some other small detail in visual style to make the three lines of text feel like it comes from your app. Also, users placed these widgets manually on the Lock Screen so we think that users will remember which app the information is coming from.

If your app is all about lists of information, hopefully there’s some visual detail that you can bring forward to the Lock Screen.

If your app is all about lists of information, hopefully there’s some visual detail that you can bring forward to the Lock Screen.

<@U045ZRTH5A9> asked
> Are there any restrictions / guidelines around showing live workout data in live activities? How frequently can I refresh the data being shown in the dynamic island?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Are there any restrictions \/ guidelines around showing live workout data in live activities? How frequently can I refresh the data being shown in the dynamic island?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question! Are you planning to use some background runtime like location services to update your Live Activity? Or are you planning to use APNs pushes?

elements.text: Great question! Are you planning to use some background runtime like location services to update your Live Activity? Or are you planning to use APNs pushes?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you’re planning to use background runtime, you can update your Live Activity whenever the values for the activity have changed. You want to make sure you’re not over-updating however, as this could cause significant battery usage.

elements.text: If you’re planning to use background runtime, you can update your Live Activity whenever the values for the activity have changed. You want to make sure you’re not over-updating however, as this could cause significant battery usage.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Most likely a combination of background runtime, location services and Bluetooth devices to handle the updates. Definitely keen on making sure the battery doesn’t get significantly drained.

elements.text: Most likely a combination of background runtime, location services and Bluetooth devices to handle the updates
Definitely keen on making sure the battery
doesn’t
get significantly drained

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Regarding what to put in your activity, I’d suggest thinking about the most essential pieces of information about your workout that you’re trying to convey (such as workout type, elapsed time, calories burned, etc). You could show the most essential piece of information in the compact island view, and more pieces of information in the expanded view and the lock screen platter. You should update them as frequently as possible in both views to make it feel as “live” as possible.

elements.text: Regarding what to put in your activity, I’d suggest thinking about the most essential pieces of information about your workout that you’re trying to convey (such as workout type, elapsed time, calories burned, etc). You could show the most essential piece of information in the compact island view, and more pieces of information in the expanded view and the lock screen platter. You should update them as frequently as possible in both views to make it feel as “live” as possible.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: <@U045ZRTH5A9> the best way to avoid excess battery drain is to only update your Live Activities when new values are ready for display. Location services and bluetooth runtime are excellent ways to provide those updates, though!

elements.text: the best way to avoid excess battery drain is to only update your Live Activities when new values are ready for display. Location services and bluetooth runtime are excellent ways to provide those updates, though!

In regards to your expanded Dynamic Island presentation, it would be great to have the state circles (drip and clock glyphs) to be concentric to both ends of the Dynamic Island for a visual harmony. Both circles currently do not appear to be vertically centered.

Also, it would be good to have all the buttons in the Dynamic Island be big enough to ensure sufficient tap targets.

elements.text:
In regards to your expanded Dynamic Island presentation, it would be great to have the state circles (drip and clock glyphs) to be concentric to both ends of the Dynamic Island for a visual harmony. Both circles currently do not appear to be vertically centered.

Also, it would be good to have all the buttons in the Dynamic Island be big enough to ensure sufficient tap targets.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Alternatively, it could be great idea to present the same button controls from inside the app to provide familiar controls to the users when the app goes into the Dynamic Island.

elements.text: Alternatively, it could be great idea to present the same button controls from inside the app to provide familiar controls to the users when the app goes into the Dynamic Island.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
In regards to this expanded Dynamic Island presentation, it would be great to avoid showing any empty blank space on the top of the island to ensure that we are utilizing the screen real estate to the fullest and to enable a seamless integration of hardware and software.

The pause/download buttons and the time counter could use a bigger size to ensure sufficient tap target sizes and increased legibility. Buttons in the iOS Clock Timer expanded presentation would be a good reference for this view.

elements.text:
In regards to this expanded Dynamic Island presentation, it would be great to avoid showing any empty blank space on the top of the island to ensure that we are utilizing the screen real estate to the fullest and to enable a seamless integration of hardware and software.

The pause/download buttons and the time counter could use a bigger size to ensure sufficient tap target sizes and increased legibility. Buttons in the iOS Clock Timer expanded presentation would be a good reference for this view.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In the case for your compact presentations, both the leading and trailing elements appear to have additional space between the assets and the sensor housing. It would be ideal to have the circle and the ‘0:36’ counter to be placed as close to the sensor as possible to make the compact presentation as narrowly tucked in as possible. Please see these two for comparison.

Please see these two for comparison.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Additionally, the time counter could be bigger for increased legibility. A good size reference for the time counter would be the iOS Clock Timer.

elements.text: Additionally, the time counter could be bigger for increased legibility. A good size reference for the time counter would be the iOS Clock Timer.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Another suggestion for the compact presentation is to have the glyphs to be tinted instead of being placed in a gradient circle. The Dynamic Island is already in an oval shape, so it could be easier on the eyes to just see the tinted symbol on the Dynamic Island.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: While a Live Activity is active it occupies a prominent place on both the Lock Screen and in the Dynamic Island, so it’s important the information being displayed is something the user is trying to keep an eye on for the entire duration of the experience. Live Activities are best used to represent information with an explicit start and end time on the scale of a few minutes to several hours, such as a workout or a sports game.

:bulb:One of the more powerful experiences we’ve discussed with folks about Live Activities is the ability to present different UI depending on what phase the activity is in — in a sports example, you may want a different UI for the pre-game state than you would present during or after the game.

What sort of creative ideas have you all been brainstorming about the life cycles of your Live Activities?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: yes. in a workout, users can use the crown and the action button. Likewise in an underwater dive session.

messages.text:
<@U046FS54ELA> asked
> As a swimming app, it is necessary for our users to have water lock on for 95% of the time they use our watch app. We are doing our best to come up with use cases that are good on the Ultra with the Action Button but we are hesitant to put any _new_ functionality behind the Action Button because it means the rest of our user base (Series 8 and below) would not be able to access it.
> 
> One option we are looking at is adding a menu of already-implemented actions on the capacitive screen. Ex:
> 1. Hit Action Button
> 2. Custom menu appears
> 3. User can scroll through menu items to highlight them
> 4. Hit Action Button again to select the highlighted action (ex: "End Workout") 
> 
> Do you have any feedback on this approach or suggestions to make sure anything we add to Action Button can also be used by non-Ultra users?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"As a swimming app, it is necessary for our users to have water lock on for 95% of the time they use our watch app. We are doing our best to come up with use cases that are good on the Ultra with the Action Button but we are hesitant to put any _new_ functionality behind the Action Button because it means the rest of our user base (Series 8 and below) would not be able to access it.

One option we are looking at is adding a menu of already-implemented actions on the capacitive screen. Ex:
1. Hit Action Button
2. Custom menu appears
3. User can scroll through menu items to highlight them
4. Hit Action Button again to select the highlighted action (ex: "End Workout") 

Do you have any feedback on this approach or suggestions to make sure anything we add to Action Button can also be used by non-Ultra users?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: A good guideline is not to offer a feature that is isolated to the Action button without also offering it in the UI elsewhere. The Action Button should be understood as an accelerator, not a requirement for a feature to work.

elements.text: A good guideline is not to offer a feature that is isolated to the Action button without also offering it in the UI elsewhere. The Action Button should be understood as an accelerator, not a requirement for a feature to work.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In general, outside of underwater dive sessions, we encourage the action button to be a fast, accelerated, interaction rather than a method for extensive navigation.

elements.text: In general, outside of underwater dive sessions, we encourage the action button to be a fast, accelerated, interaction rather than a method for extensive navigation.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would be interested to know how many options you have in your Custom menu, and if it's possible to map them to just use the Action button and a Chord.

elements.text: I would be interested to know how many options you have in your Custom menu, and if it's possible to map them to just use the Action button and a Chord.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Perhaps a good analogy is in our 1st party workout app. We have controls that are available to all watch users Series and Ultra, which is available by swiping left.

elements.text: Perhaps a good analogy is in our 1st party workout app. We have controls that are available to all watch users Series and Ultra, which is available by swiping left.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In Ultra, not all of the controls are exposed to the Action button, but just the ones we think are critical to advancing and controlling the workout.

elements.text: In Ultra, not all of the controls are exposed to the Action button, but just the ones we think are critical to advancing and controlling the workout.

We already have pause/resume intents mapped to the chord but haven't figured out the best strategy for the Action Button alone so don't have anything special mapped to it beyond "Start Workout"

messages.text: <@U044JNMC9RS> A common question that has come up around the Action button is whether an app should try to instruct, or onboard, people in how to use it. Do you have any thoughts or guidance here?

elements.text: A common question that has come up around the Action button is whether an app should try to instruct, or onboard, people in how to use it. Do you have any thoughts or guidance here?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In general we encourage developers not to create their own instructions/onboarding given that the system will provide visual hints telling the user what the action button will do. Additionally, each time the action button changes its function (e.g. Going from Start Workout  to Next Leg in Workout) a hint will appear to educate users of the change.

elements.text: In general we encourage developers not to create their own instructions/onboarding given that the system will provide visual hints telling the user what the action button will do. Additionally, each time the action button changes its function (e.g. Going from Start Workout  to Next Leg in Workout) a hint will appear to educate users of the change.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: In addition, there will be illustrated tutorials in the Action Button Settings which are constructed using the verbs developers provide.

elements.text: In addition, there will be illustrated tutorials in the Action Button Settings which are constructed using the verbs developers provide.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The Hints mentioned above do not always show however, they will go away after appearing a few times.

elements.text: The Hints mentioned above do not always show however, they will go away after appearing a few times.

messages.text: <@U044JNMC9RS> Another common question: Do you have any suggestions around the naming or labeling of actions for the Action button?

elements.text: Another common question: Do you have any suggestions around the naming or labeling of actions for the Action button?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (This is an editorial question, I guess. What’s a good action name?)

elements.text: (This is an editorial question, I guess. What’s a good action name?)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Good question. We recommend short and concise descriptions. Usually a single present tense, active voice, verb with a direct object. And omitting articles like "the, or a"  For example a good one is "Start Workout". We would not do something like "Start a Workout"

Thanks <@U0449EV4WHL>!

If I have 10 issues for the Apple iOS UI library, can that be submitted as a list within a single submission or does it need to be 10 separate submissions?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
I’m not <@U0449EV4WHL> BUT as someone who files (and reads) a fair amount of feedback, I’d say it depends on how closely related those issues are. Think of individual feedback as a to-do list item — are these issues that could be triaged at the same time or would they require different work streams to solve?

If they’re markedly different from each other, I’d recommend separate submissions for each of those. If you feel like they’re things that can be accomplished in one go, group them!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Great question! We're on the lookout for apps and games that really excel in 6 different categories of design:
• Innovation 
• Interaction
• Visuals & Graphics
• Delight & Fun
• Inclusivity
• Social Impact 
We actually have a few blurbs about the each category on our website as well as interviews with the winners from last year that go into specifics: <https://developer.apple.com/design/awards/>

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What's the recommended way to use Custom SF Symbols with the official Apple Sketch Libraries since custom SF Symbols that have been dragged into the SF Symbols Mac app can't be copied and pasted into the Sketch library symbol's icon override fields, like regular SF Symbols can."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great question! Unfortunately the answer isn’t great. I don’t believe there’s a way to use custom symbols in the same way we’ve set up the files for using SF Symbols as they can’t be added to the SF Pro or SF Compact font.

elements.text: Great question! Unfortunately the answer isn’t great. I don’t believe there’s a way to use custom symbols in the same way we’ve set up the files for using SF Symbols as they can’t be added to the SF Pro or SF Compact font.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The only option I think would be to detach the symbol from the main library. At which point you lose some of the benefit of using the library. :confused:

Heya Ivan! If you're talking about placing text in the "world space" vs. "screen space" of your app we have a few suggestions:

messages.text:
<@U046U1BQ9B2> asked
> How should I approach designing Colors in my app? The new Human Interface guidelines say that "In a nongame app, overuse of color can make communication less clear and can be distracting". I often have trouble choosing what colors to use and how many - is there a guideline for how many colors and how many shades we should use? For example, let's say I'm designing a skiing news client app. I want to use blue and white, but how many different variations of these colors should I have?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How should I approach designing Colors in my app? The new Human Interface guidelines say that \"In a nongame app, overuse of color can make communication less clear and can be distracting\". I often have trouble choosing what colors to use and how many - is there a guideline for how many colors and how many shades we should use? For example, let's say I'm designing a skiing news client app. I want to use blue and white, but how many different variations of these colors should I have?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
This is a great question. Color is really important and a popular topic in design. When we think about color for apps specifically, think about how color can be a way to communicate to your users what on the interface is tappable. Without the use of physical buttons, it’s important we use other techniques to hint at interaction and color is one great way to do this!

You’ll notice our first-party apps all have one key tint color. For example, Mail is blue and Podcasts is purple. Using color for actions is a subtle way to brand the interface without being too distracting or intrusive. When incorporating your brand colors in other elements, such as a set of icons, just be mindful of how color adds value to the experience oppose to doing it for the sake of visual design. Hope this helps!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I would start with a main tint color, establish your workflows and actions and sketch those out with the tint color representing actions. As Mike was mentioning in News, the sections with background colors behind text and coordinating headers. Using the same two colors in this example, minimizes overuse of color for the sake of it

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Live Activities have a few limitations given the intent for them to highlight a live event, or the progress of a task going on in your app.

elements.text: Live Activities have a few limitations given the intent for them to highlight a live event, or the progress of a task going on in your app.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: First, a Live Activity can only begin when your app is in the foreground, or by using other system interactions like an App Shortcut — iOS 16.1 RC has a new App Intent protocol named <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appintents/liveactivitystartingintent|LiveActivityStartingIntent> that allows you to start a Live Activity from an App Intent invocation

LiveActivityStartingIntent
that allows you to start a Live Activity from an App Intent invocation

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Furthermore, Live Activities can only be updated when your app has background runtime, or by pushing updates over APNs. You’re right that background audio runtime isn’t supported for updating a Live Activity, so your best bet here is to either use some other background runtime that your app already has, or to investigate using APNs to push updates remotely.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
> Is there no way to finish a process the user wants finished even if they’re not currently in the app?
There’s no way to accomplish that for Live Activities — app extensions in general can run in the background when the app isn’t running, but there’s no “process” here that you’re in control of. Scheduling local notifications would work well for alerting the user, but they don’t provide any sort of additional background runtime like a remote notification does when you implement a Notification Service Extension (NSE)

messages.text:
<@U045PHMLFFZ> asked
> Do you always try to adhere as much as possible to the HIG when designing apps, or do you try to do something a little different with every design?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Do you always try to adhere as much as possible to the HIG when designing apps, or do you try to do something a little different with every design? "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Great question! We try as much as possible to do adhere to our foundations and follow our own design patterns for the benefit of consistency and understanding. We also try to use system components because they're so efficient to build with.

That being said we're willing to push on the HIG where it makes sense if it's an overall benefit for users. We're pretty adamant that HIG shouldn't be a set of rules, but very good suggestions. We evolve it constantly based on what we're seeing in the outside community and how we want to push our own aesthetics and interactions for the future

For instance, if I'm a social app and I've got three tabs:\nhouse, magnifyingglass, person.crop.circle\nIt's a pretty common pattern, especially for a social app. Is it still necessary to include labels for \"Home\", \"Search\", \"Profile\"?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Sam, great question. Labels are recommended in many cases for accessibility and simply, clarity. Tab bars specifically are a central control to navigate your apps content, so using them correctly is really important. The categories within your tabs should be clear and representative of your apps content. In the example you mention above, Home/Search/Profile could really be any app. The lack of specificity means it may be hard to discern what content and features are within each tab. Part of the exercise of labeling tabs is being really clear about what they represent.

<@U045PHMLFFZ> asked
> Does it happen where there are too many features are in an app and some have to be cut to make an app feel less cluttered/more user friendly? Or do you try to move that feature to somewhere better?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Does it happen where there are too many features are in an app and some have to be cut to make an app feel less cluttered\/more user friendly? Or do you try to move that feature to somewhere better? "}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
This is a great exercise to do on a whiteboard or with sticky notes: Try taking all the features/areas of your app and write them down, bucket them into what fulfills the goals your users will have when using your app. If there's something that feels superfluous, definitely consider whether you need that feature/area to be there. There's a balance between what you need visible all the time, what can be a few taps away vs. what doesn't need to be there at all.

This is also a helpful way to prioritize what the most important functionality/views of your app are which can help you organize your app's hierarchy. We go over some of this in the talk <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10126/|Discoverable Design >if you want to know more.

There's a balance between what you need visible all the time, what can be a few taps away vs. what doesn't need to be there at all.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Depends on the purpose of the app, it can be hard to define how many is “too many”. It will be helpful to think about the experience of what you want people to accomplish in the app. Go through the content and features to see if they fall under the same core concepts. After all it’s about if the hierarchy is clear and easy to navigate, and the app helps people accomplish their goals at ease.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We love when apps support both portrait and landscape orientations – you can really leave this up to the user to decide whether they want device orientation locked or unlocked through their settings. slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Sam, for the most part we use a top-down light source as you’ve noted. The light source tends to be pretty close to the viewer’s perspective. Meaning the Y offset is pretty minimal. But it can vary based a bit on taste / context. A bigger Y-offset will help the content the shadow is cast from appear to advance closer to the user’s perspective. Doesn’t necessarily mean the light source angle is is different

Would there be any different considerations if this was macOS or iOS or iPadOS?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi <@U045ZRTH5A9>! The map is great for showing location context of where a workout/activity started or ended. When it comes to metrics though, displaying those in a separate UI view from the map is best since it'll give you more space to display all info you want. You could accomplish this with a card UI (like the one we use in the Maps app), or something like an overlay.

elements.text: Hi

! The map is great for showing location context of where a workout/activity started or ended. When it comes to metrics though, displaying those in a separate UI view from the map is best since it'll give you more space to display all info you want. You could accomplish this with a card UI (like the one we use in the Maps app), or something like an overlay.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi <@U04660ZCPPE>, great question! You can let Maps know if we're missing or have inaccurate street data by Reporting an Issue through our iOS or macOS apps. The more information you can provide the better! Once we make the correction on our side it will be updated for all users (a new drive isn't always required). On iOS, you can scroll to the very bottom of the card that appears when you open the app. You should see a "Report an Issue" button. On macOS you can find it from the file menu Maps > Report an Issue...

<@U0468P6C81G> asked
> We're a major moving company and are considering a feature that shows the customer's location history during a truck rental. As a rental may span many hours, or even days, and we want to accurately show their driving history, this could be _many_ data points.
> 
> I'd like to present this information similar to how you can see your location history during a walk Workout. I tried copying that by creating an MKPolyline over all of the coordinates, and then use a custom MKOverlay for each individual point.
> 
> Would that be the most performant way of doing something like this? I found the simulator, and device, lagging a bit when trying to display a dot for about 12,000 data points, and that was just a small subset of data.

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Josh, thank you for the question. You've got a pretty large data set, and it could help to simplify the information you're displaying. A user might not need to know their location history in such fine detail, and reducing the number of points could create a lighter-weight implementation without detracting from the user experience.

elements.text: Hey Josh, thank you for the question. You've got a pretty large data set, and it could help to simplify the information you're displaying. A user might not need to know their location history in such fine detail, and reducing the number of points could create a lighter-weight implementation without detracting from the user experience.

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
For the user, definitely.

Would it make sense to change the number of points being displayed based on zoom level? Or is the calculation/re-application of overlays expensive as you zoom in/out?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From a design perspective, it certainly makes sense to progressively disclose dense information across multiple zoom levels. Depending on the number of points, you still might run into implementation challenges, but that is definitely the right place to start.

Thank you!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Definitely! Maps-based experiences can be quite complex. My advice would be to focus on displaying one or two key use cases at a time. You can utilize progressive disclosure and allow users to drill into different topics with a focused view of just that topic.

Hey <@U0464NE480L>, we have a section on the Human Interface Guidelines that covers a few considerations for indoor maps, such as:
• Adjust map detail based on the zoom level
• Use distinctive styling to differentiate the features of your map
• Offer a floor picker if your venue includes multiple levels
• Include surrounding areas to provide context
• and more!

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hey <@U046S70K9A4>! Great question. Search results do have some text properties such as name, address and URL that could be read out loud. Below are some resources that would be helpful for achieving this...

Check out the API documentation for `AVSpeechSynthesizer` which can be used to read aloud textual information.
<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/avfaudio/avspeechsynthesizer>

As for search results, they are returned in the form of `MKMapItem` objects. Documentation for those can be found here:
<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/mapkit/mkmapitem>

messages.text:
<@U0462P4V5M0> asked
> How should we be thinking about the hover feature? 1:1 with pointer hover behavior? Or something completely novel?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How should we be thinking about the hover feature? 1:1 with pointer hover behavior? Or something completely novel?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: From an art perspective, we were trying to bridge the gap between a digital pencil, and traditional media like a paint brush. If you look at a paint brush and dip it in some red paint, you have a rough idea of the kind of mark it will make on the canvas. Hover helps the user understand what will happen when you make a mark with the Apple Pencil before you make it.

elements.text: From an art perspective, we were trying to bridge the gap between a digital pencil, and traditional media like a paint brush. If you look at a paint brush and dip it in some red paint, you have a rough idea of the kind of mark it will make on the canvas. Hover helps the user understand what will happen when you make a mark with the Apple Pencil before you make it.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ah, so it’s sort of like an additional level of forgiveness on top of more traditional features like undo/redo and version history?

elements.text: Ah, so it’s sort of like an additional level of forgiveness on top of more traditional features like undo/redo and version history?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Exactly. It can help give the user confidence about what mark they will make. So it hopefully helps the user to use the undo button less.

elements.text: Exactly. It can help give the user confidence about what mark they will make. So it hopefully helps the user to use the undo button less.

messages.text:
Thank you everyone for joining our week of Q&A’s for Ask Apple! We had a lot of fun here in the Design channel. If you weren’t able to join us live, be sure to scroll through the Q&A’s for our discussions.

As a reminder our office hours *Ask a Design Evangelist* are tomorrow from 9:00-1:00pm. Keep an eye on your inbox to see if your appointments have been selected. Have a wonderful rest of the week :wave::skin-tone-2:
